Description: The French teacher,  wore his beautiful green coat, his frilled shirt, and the little black silk cap, all embroidered, that he never wore except on inspection and prize days.  He was kind, patient, and deeply saddened by the loss of his job and the suppression of the French language. He showed his love for his country and language by writing 'Vive La France!' on the blackboard. He had taught for 40 years at the same school.

The main character, a young boy who is reluctant to attend school but attends his last French lesson. He is initially in great dread of a scolding from M. Hamel, and is tempted to run away, but resists and attends the lesson. He deeply regrets not having learned his lessons earlier and is affected by the realization that it's his last French lesson. He is ashamed that he cannot fully answer the teacher's questions and struggles with his feelings as he recognizes the significance of the situation and his own shortcomings.
A blacksmith who sees Little Franz running to school. He makes a comment, “Don’t go so fast, bub; you’ll get to your school in plenty of time!” implying that there is no need to hurry.

An elderly villager, who attends the final class. He brings an old primer, thumbed at the edges, showcasing his remorse for not taking more advantage of his educational opportunities. He cries during the class, and his emotional reaction highlights the shared sadness in the community over the loss of their language and culture.  He is shown holding his primer, spelling out the letters with his spectacles.

Soldiers seen drilling in the open field, symbolizing the invasion and the consequences of the Franco-Prussian War for the French people. They represent the German authority and the impending change in the educational system.

Several villagers attend M. Hamel's last class, sitting quietly on the back benches. Their presence shows their regret for not having attended school more diligently and their respect for M. Hamel and the French language.
